info.title: Understanding Literary Texts About Making Mistakes
info.lesson_objectives:
• Analyze sentences to understand the most important ideas in a text.
  • Examine common sentence elements and how they build meaning in a text.
  • Examine sentences with complex structure and recognize sentence parts in order to build meaning in a text.
info.lesson_standards:
RL.7.1 Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
L.7.3 Use knowledge of language and its conventions when [writing, speaking,] reading, [or listening].

target_sentence_text.value: While I am super excited about attending a Chinese New Year party , I am also pretty nervous.

parts.alt: While I am super excited about <blank> , I am also pretty nervous.
attending a Chinese New Year party

correct_answers.rationale_for_answer: Students who chose this response recognize that "my brain conjures up all the ways I might humiliate myself at my first Chinese New Year celebration" suggests that the narrator is nervous about attending a Chinese New Year party.

distractor_text.value: visiting Kai’s house for the first time

parts.alt: visiting Kai’s house for the first time

distractors.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read "walking up to my friend Kai's house" and assumed that the narrator's nervousness was due to her visiting her friend's house for the first time. However, "my brain conjures up all the ways I might humiliate myself at my first Chinese New Year celebration" suggests that the narrator is nervous about attending a Chinese New Year party.

distractor_text.value: introducing the family to a new holiday

parts.alt: introducing the family to a new holiday

distractors.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read "first Chinese New Year celebration" and "holiday for his family" and assumed that the narrator was introducing Kai's family to a new holiday. However, "my brain conjures up all the ways I might humiliate myself at my first Chinese New Year celebration" suggests that the narrator is nervous about attending a Chinese New Year party.

parts.alt: "Lucky Red," by Brooks Benjamin

part1_stem_text.value: Who is the narrator of this story? Tap your answer.

part1_stem.rationale_for_answer: Students who chose this response recognize that Kai's father is addressing the narrator when he opens the door and says "Hi, Mackenzie." This is reinforced when the narrator notes that he has a welcoming smile but all she sees is his red bowtie.

part1_clickable_answer_distractors.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read Mr. Li's name in the story and assumed that because he opened the door, he is the narrator. However, Kai's father is addressing the narrator when he opens the door and says "Hi, Mackenzie," suggesting that Mackenzie is the narrator. This is reinforced when the narrator notes that Mr. Li has a welcoming smile but all she sees is his red bowtie.

Students may have chosen this response if they read that the New Year celebration was at Kai's house and assumed that Kai was the narrator. However, Kai's father addresses the narrator when he opens the door and says "Hi, Mackenzie," suggesting that Mackenzie is the narrator. This is reinforced when the narrator notes that he has a welcoming smile but all she sees is his red bowtie.

However, "my brain conjures up all the ways I might humiliate myself" suggests that the narrator is worried about embarrassing herself at the celebration.

text.value: Fill in the blanks to explain why Mackenzie compares Mr. Li’s bowtie to a stop sign.

parts.alt: Fill in the blanks to explain why Mackenzie compares Mr. Li's bowtie to a stop sign.

maze_text.value: Like a stop sign, the bowtie is a sudden alert. It signals, "Wait! You forgot to wear red."

parts.alt: Like a stop sign, the bowtie is a <blank>. It signals, <blank>

answer_text.rationale_for_answer: Students who chose this response recognize that the bowtie is an immediate alert, preventing Mackenzie from going any further, just as a stop sign warns a driver to stop and look around before proceeding.

Students may have chosen this response if they read that Mr. Li greets Mackenzie with a welcoming smile while wearing the bowtie. But the bowtie is alerting Mackenzie to her mistake, just as a stop sign tells a driver to stop and look around before proceeding.

Students may have chosen this response if they inferred that the author was focused on the stop sign's shape rather than its function. However, the bowtie alerts Mackenzie to her mistake, just as a stop sign tells a driver to stop and look around before proceeding.
Students who chose this response recognize that "reminding me what I've forgotten" and "I was supposed to wear red . . ." suggest that the bowtie tells Mackenzie that she forgot to wear red.

answer_text.answer_text: “Hold on! You should have a tie.”
answer_text.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response because they've reasoned that the comparison is more related to the bowtie than to the its color. However, "reminding me what I've forgotten" and "I was supposed to wear red . . ." suggest that the bowtie tells Mackenzie that she forgot to wear red.

answer_text.answer_text: “Oh no! You failed to say hello.”
answer_text.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read that, instead of greeting Mr. Li, Mackenzie focuses on his bowtie. However, "reminding me what I've forgotten" and "I was supposed to wear red . . ." suggest that the bowtie tells Mackenzie that she forgot to wear red.

“I’ve checked <blank> FIVE times.”
the backpack

correct_answers.rationale_for_answer: Students who chose this response recognize that when the narrator says Mateo sifted through his backpack once more, and then immediately responds that he's checked five times, the clear implication is that he checked the backpack.

parts.alt: the trio

distractors.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read that Mateo is the third member of their trio and assumed that he was checking the trio five times. However, when the narrator says Mateo sifted through his backpack once more, and then immediately responds that he's checked five times, the clear implication is that he checked the backpack.

parts.alt: the audience

distractors.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read in the previous paragraph about the narrator peeking through the curtains "at the audience" and he was checking the audience again. However, when the narrator says Mateo sifted through his backpack once more, and then immediately responds that he's checked five times, the clear implication is that he checked the backpack.

parts.alt: the tie

distractors.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read that Mateo checked and then read "tie." However, Mateo was checking the backpack FOR the tie. When the narrator says Mateo sifted through his backpack once more, and then immediately responds that he's checked five times, the clear implication is that he checked the backpack.

part1_stem.rationale_for_answer: Students who chose this response recognize that if Mateo is sifting through "my backpack" and then says "your tie is not here, James," the implication is that James is the narrator.

part1_clickable_answer_distractors.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read that Nisha demanded Mateo check again and the narrator notes that Mateo sifted through "my backpack," possibly leading them to believe the backpack belongs to Nisha, making her the narrator. However, if Mateo is sifting through "my backpack" and then says "your tie is not here, James," the implication is that James is the narrator.

Students may have chosen this response if they read that Mateo was sifting through the backpack and assumed he was the narrator. However, if Mateo is sifting through "my backpack" and then says "your tie is not here, James," the implication is that James is the narrator.

parts.alt: What problem is the narrator having?
The narrator’s tie is missing.

part2_answer.rationale_for_answer: Students who chose this response recognize that "I was in serious trouble" and "Your tie is NOT here, James" suggests that the narrator (James) is missing his tie before the ensemble.

parts.alt: The narrator’s trio is incomplete.

part2_answer.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they noted the names of other characters but the lack of clarity about those characters led them to an inaccurate inference about one of them being absent. (And this would be a problem in a vocal ensemble competition.) However, "I was in serious trouble" and "Your tie is NOT here, James" suggests that the narrator (James) is missing his tie before the ensemble.

parts.alt: The narrator’s seat is taken.

part2_answer.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read the first part where the narrator is peeking through the curtains at the audience and notices that the seats were filled up. text.value: How does James feel when he realizes his mistake?

parts.alt: How does James feel when he realizes his mistake?

text.value: He is disappointed with himself.

parts.alt: He is disappointed with himself.

answer.rationale_for_answer: Students who chose this response recognize that James's comment that he was in serious trouble, coupled with his mumbling about where he left the tie, suggest that he is disappointed with himself.

text.value: He is embarrassed to go onstage.

parts.alt: He is embarrassed to go onstage.

answer.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they inferred that James was embarrassed to go onstage without adhering to the dress code. However, James's comment that he was in serious trouble, coupled with his mumbling about where he left the tie, suggest that he is disappointed with himself.

text.value: He is confused about the dress code.

parts.alt: He is confused about the dress code.

answer.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read that the dress code flashed through his mind and assumed that he was trying to decipher its meaning. However, his reciting of the words suggests the meaning was clear. Instead, James's comment that he was in serious trouble, coupled with his mumbling about where he left the tie, suggest that he is disappointed with himself.

text.value: He is frustrated with his friends.

parts.alt: He is frustrated with his friends.

answer.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read that Nisha spoke in a harsh whisper and Mateo seemed to speak sharply (FIVE times), and inferred that James was frustrated with his friends. However, James's comment that he was in serious trouble, coupled with his mumbling about where he left the tie, suggest that he is disappointed with himself.

target_sentence_text.value: Nisha ran over to a large cabinet with a spark in her eyes and then opened the cabinet doors and spilled decorations on the floor .

parts.alt: Nisha <blank> with a spark in her eyes and then <blank> and <blank> .
ran over to a large cabinet

correct_answers.rationale_for_answer: Students who chose this response recognize that the first action Nisha does is run over to the cabinet, which coincides with her getting a spark in her eyes.

parts.alt: opened the cabinet doors

correct_answers.rationale_for_answer: Students who chose this response recognize that after running to the large cabinet, Nisha's next action is opening the cabinet doors.

parts.alt: spilled decorations on the floor

correct_answers.rationale_for_answer: Students who chose this response recognize that the result of opening the cabinet doors is that she spills decorations on the floor. This is also the last action that is performed.

text.value: Why did Nisha have a “spark in her eyes”?

parts.alt: Why did Nisha have a “spark in her eyes”?

text.value: She thought of a new way to follow the dress code.

parts.alt: She thought of a new way to follow the dress code.

answer.rationale_for_answer: Students who chose this response recognize that Nisha's determination to "fix this" and her heading for the cabinet suggest that the spark in her eye indicates she had a solution to the lost tie problem by devising a way to meet the dress code rule after all.

text.value: She felt excited because she was going to sing onstage.

parts.alt: She felt excited because she was going to sing onstage.

answer.rationale_for_answer: Students may have chosen this response if they read that the trio were going to perform in the singing competition and assumed that the spark in Nisha's eyes had to do with her excitement about performing. However, Nisha's determination to "fix this" and her heading for the cabinet suggest that the spark in her eye indicates she had a solution to the lost tie problem by devising a way to meet the dress code rule after all.

text.value: She felt annoyed because James forgot his green tie.

ops.insert: Walking up to my friend Kai’s house, I imagine all the ways I might
myself at my first Chinese New Year celebration. Kai had explained that it’s an important holiday for his family, and while I am super excited about it, I am also pretty nervous.
“Hi, Mackenzie!” Kai’s father, Mr. Li, answers the door with a welcoming smile, but all I notice is his red bowtie facing me like a stop sign, reminding me what I’ve forgotten.
I think, slapping my palm to my forehead.
I was supposed to wear red because it’s lucky.
“Come this way, Mackenzie!” Kai shouts as I step inside, and then he pulls me into the kitchen, where he’s helping to prepare dinner.
“Hold on, Kai,” I whisper in embarrassment. “I forgot about wearing red!”
“Don’t worry,” he says, holding out a plate of steaming dumplings. “Try a dumpling! We made traditional pork and my new creation: pizza dumplings!”

I pick up a pizza dumpling and attempt a delicate bite, but a glob of pizza sauce dribbles out onto my white socks. Feeling completely embarrassed, I scan the room for the nearest place to hide for the rest of the evening.
“Look, Mackenzie!” Kai says with an amused grin. “You remembered to wear red after all!”
Kai’s mother playfully swats him with a dish towel. “Don’t worry, dear. I got attacked by the sauce, too!”
As she sticks out her foot to reveal her own red-stained sock, I burst out laughing.
This is going to be a great New Year.

parts.alt: Lucky Red
by Brooks Benjamin
Walking up to my friend Kai’s house, I imagine all the ways I might humiliate myself at my first Chinese New Year celebration.
Kai had explained that it’s an important holiday for his family, and while I am super excited about it, I am also pretty nervous.
“Hi, Mackenzie!” Kai’s father, Mr. Li, answers the door with a welcoming smile, but all I notice is his red bowtie facing me like a stop sign, reminding me what I’ve forgotten.
Red!
I think, slapping my palm to my forehead.
I was supposed to wear red because it’s lucky.
“Come this way, Mackenzie!” Kai shouts as I step inside, and then he pulls me into the kitchen, where he’s helping to prepare dinner.
“Hold on, Kai,” I whisper in embarrassment.
“I forgot about wearing red!”
“Don’t worry,” he says, holding out a plate of steaming dumplings.
“Try a dumpling!
We made traditional pork and my new creation: pizza dumplings!”
I pick up a pizza dumpling and attempt a delicate bite, but a glob of pizza sauce dribbles out onto my white socks.
Feeling completely embarrassed, I scan the room for the nearest place to hide for the rest of the evening.
“Look, Mackenzie!” Kai says with an amused grin.
“You remembered to wear red after all!”
Kai’s mother playfully swats him with a dish towel.
“Don’t worry, dear.
I got attacked by the sauce, too!”
As she sticks out her foot to reveal her own red-stained sock, I burst out laughing.
This is going to be a great New Year.

ops.insert: With only ten minutes until the
competition began, I peeked through the curtains at the audience as the seats filled up. I was in serious trouble.
“Check again,” Nisha demanded in a harsh whisper, trying to ignore the curious glances from other teams.
Mateo, the third member of our trio, sifted through my backpack once more. “I’ve checked FIVE times. The tie is NOT here, James,” he said.
“I’m pretty sure I left it hanging on my door,” I mumbled as the event’s dress code flashed through my mind:
All performers must wear a jacket and tie featuring their school colors.
“Okay,” Nisha said with determination. “We can fix this.”
“How?” Mateo said, slumping against the wall. “Where are we going to find another green tie in the next ten minutes?”

With a spark in her eyes, Nisha ran over to a large cabinet and pulled open its doors, spilling an avalanche of random decorations onto the floor. Moments later, she came back with three enormous glitter-encrusted green bows that had decorated the gym for the last school dance. “Hurry, put these on!”
glance, but then shrugged and grinned as if to say
With our new bowties on, we checked out each other’s appearances, laughing at how ridiculous we looked…but glad to look ridiculous together.

assets.alt_text: A boy peeking out from behind curtains on a stage in front of a packed audience. A spotlight shines between the parted curtains.

parts.alt: Backstage Blunder
by Brooks Benjamin
With only ten minutes until the vocal ensemble competition began, I peeked through the curtains at the audience as the seats filled up.
I was in serious trouble.
“Check again,” Nisha demanded in a harsh whisper, trying to ignore the curious glances from other teams.
Mateo, the third member of our trio, sifted through my backpack once more.
“I’ve checked FIVE times.
The tie is NOT here, James,” he said.
“I’m pretty sure I left it hanging on my door,” I mumbled as the event’s dress code flashed through my mind: All performers must wear a jacket and tie featuring their school colors.
“Okay,” Nisha said with determination.
“We can fix this.”
“How?” Mateo said, slumping against the wall.
“Where are we going to find another green tie in the next ten minutes?”
With a spark in her eyes, Nisha ran over to a large cabinet and pulled open its doors, spilling an avalanche of random decorations onto the floor.
Moments later, she came back with three enormous glitter-encrusted green bows that had decorated the gym for the last school dance.
“Hurry, put these on!”
Mateo and I exchanged an apprehensive glance, but then shrugged and grinned as if to say What choice do we have?
With our new bowties on, we checked out each other’s appearances, laughing at how ridiculous we looked…but glad to look ridiculous together.

parts.alt: Walking up to my friend Kai’s house, I imagine all the ways I might humiliate myself at my first Chinese New Year celebration.
Kai had explained that it’s an important holiday for his family, and while I am super excited about it, I am also pretty nervous.

ops.insert: “Hold on, Kai,” I whisper in embarrassment. “I forgot about wearing red!”
“Don’t worry,” he says, holding out a plate of steaming dumplings. “Try a dumpling! We made traditional pork and my new creation: pizza dumplings!”

ops.insert: “Check again,” Nisha demanded in a harsh whisper, trying to ignore the curious glances from other teams.
Mateo, the third member of our trio, sifted through my backpack once more. “I’ve checked FIVE times. The tie is NOT here, James,” he said.

definition.value: When you humiliate yourself, you do something that causes feelings of shame or deep embarrassment.

parts.alt: humiliate : When you humiliate yourself, you do something that causes feelings of shame or deep embarrassment.

spanish_definition.value: Cuando alguien se humilla, hace algo que le causa vergüenza o bochorno.

parts.alt: humillarse : Cuando alguien se humilla, hace algo que le causa vergüenza o bochorno.

definition.value: A vocal ensemble is a group of singers who perform together.

parts.alt: vocal ensemble : A vocal ensemble is a group of singers who perform together.

spanish_definition.value: Un conjunto vocal es un grupo de cantantes que cantan juntos para el público.

parts.alt: conjunto vocal : Un conjunto vocal es un grupo de cantantes que cantan juntos para el público.

definition.value: If you are apprehensive, you feel worried that something bad will happen.

parts.alt: apprehensive : If you are apprehensive, you feel worried that something bad will happen.

spanish_definition.value: Si alguien se siente aprensivo, está preocupado porque cree que algo malo va a suceder.

parts.alt: aprensivo : Si alguien se siente aprensivo, está preocupado porque cree que algo malo va a suceder.

definition.value: The narrator is the voice that tells a story. Sometimes the narrator is a character in the story.

parts.alt: narrator : The narrator is the voice that tells a story. Sometimes the narrator is a character in the story.

spanish_definition.value: El narrador es la voz que relata un cuento. A veces el narrador es un personaje del cuento.

parts.alt: narrador : El narrador es la voz que relata un cuento. A veces el narrador es un personaje del cuento.
